results.title: Zoetrope to Cinemascope
results.brief_description: Not only did Alex Stitt create the first 3D animated feature film with Abra Cadabra (1983) and animate some of Australia’s most iconic commercials, including ‘Life. Be in it’, he also taught kids through play with books like this one.

constellations_primary.name: Learning through play
constellations_primary.description: Alexander Stitt and Bruce Weatherhead’s Zoetrope to Cinemascope educated children about the moving image through posters, cut-outs, puzzles and games, but moving image works have also been used to educate and entertain kids about all aspects of life.

results.description: Not only did Alex Stitt create the first 3D animated feature film with Abra Cadabra (1983) and animate some of Australia’s most iconic commercials, including ‘Life. Be in it’, he also taught kids through play. In 1971, Stitt and Bruce Weatherhead established the Jigsaw Factory in the Melbourne suburb of Richmond. The space was designed for children to have ‘fun in learning’, and the company produced a range of posters, cut-outs, educational toys, puzzles, games and books like this one, Zoetrope to cinemascope, which taught children about the relationship between optical toys and cinema.
description_for_label: Not only did Alex Stitt create the first 3D animated feature film with Abra Cadabra (1983) and animate some of Australia’s most iconic commercials, including ‘Life. Be in it’, he also taught kids through play. In 1971, Stitt and Bruce Weatherhead established the Jigsaw Factory in the Melbourne suburb of Richmond. The space was designed for children to have ‘fun in learning’, and the company produced a range of posters, cut-outs, educational toys, puzzles, games and books like this one, Zoetrope to cinemascope, which taught children about the relationship between optical toys and cinema.

results.title: Zoetrope and praxinoscope
results.brief_description: In 1834, two years after the phenakistoscope was invented in Europe, British mathematician William George Horner created his own version, the zoetrope, which used a cylindrical viewing drum containing a strip of sequenced pictures viewable through thin slits.

constellations_primary.name: Optical toys, Totoro and terrors
constellations_primary.description: Victorian-era optical toys have inspired the biggest animation studios and the scariest horror films.

results.description:
In 1834, two years after the phenakistoscope was invented in Europe, British mathematician William George Horner created his own version of the optical illusion. The Daedalum, or ‘wheel of the Devil’, used a cylindrical viewing drum containing a strip of sequenced pictures viewable through thin slits. When rotated it created the illusion of motion, and it became known as the zoetrope.

Over 40 years later, in 1877, French showman and lantern painter Charles-Émile Reynaud developed the praxinoscope, replacing the narrow viewing slots in Horner’s design with an inner circle of mirrors that more brightly reflected the pictures and let more than one person view the gliding images.
description_for_label:
In 1834, two years after the phenakistoscope was invented in Europe, British mathematician William George Horner created his own version of the optical illusion. The Daedalum, or ‘wheel of the Devil’, used a cylindrical viewing drum containing a strip of sequenced pictures viewable through thin slits. When rotated it created the illusion of motion, and it became known as the zoetrope.

Over 40 years later, in 1877, French showman and lantern painter Charles-Émile Reynaud developed the praxinoscope, replacing the narrow viewing slots in Horner’s design with an inner circle of mirrors that more brightly reflected the pictures and let more than one person view the gliding images.

results.title: Toast
results.brief_description: “Humour is a universal language,” says Edie Kurzer, and it’s an element she weaves into much of her artistic output. It’s also something that attracted her to the unique portraiture work of Sydney artist Heather Mitchell. Better known for her stage and screen presence, Mitchell has found a growing audience for her toast portraits of Australian celebrities in her medium of choice: Vegemite. Creating these slices especially for our display, she has shone a tasty spotlight on some of our most singular screen faces such as Josh Thomas, Lee Lin Chin, Deborah Mailman and others.

constellations_other.name: Ladies who own the narrative
constellations_other.description: Despite the lag in making it in mainstream cinema, female action heroes can actually be traced back to the late 19th century in early magic lantern performances of Jane Conquest, who saved both her child and a ship full of men.

results.title: Tinted film
results.brief_description: The most common methods of colouring early films were tinting and toning. Tinting was inspired by the translucent lighting gels used in theatre, while toning was adapted from photographic printing.

constellations_primary.name: Monsters, murder and mystery
constellations_primary.description: Murder and mystery hide in the shadows born from German Expressionism.

results.description: The most common methods of colouring early motion pictures were tinting and toning. Tinting was inspired by the translucent lighting gels used in theatre that washed the stage in a single glowing colour. Films were tinted by submerging frames in dye baths that saturated all the areas that weren’t black. Toning, adapted from photographic printing, coloured only the darker areas of a frame. Often, toning and tinting were both used in the one film to create moods, convey emotions and heighten tension. Other times, they were used completely randomly.
description_for_label: The most common methods of colouring early motion pictures were tinting and toning. Tinting was inspired by the translucent lighting gels used in theatre that washed the stage in a single glowing colour. Films were tinted by submerging frames in dye baths that saturated all the areas that weren’t black. Toning, adapted from photographic printing, coloured only the darker areas of a frame. Often, toning and tinting were both used in the one film to create moods, convey emotions and heighten tension. Other times, they were used completely randomly.

results.title: Thomas Alva Edison
results.brief_description: After seeing Eadweard Muybridge’s and Étienne-Jules Marey’s photography, Thomas Edison charged Scottish inventor William Dickson with developing the Kinetoscope, a large cabinet housing 50-foot loops of film that showed short movies on everything from dancing women to boxing cats.

constellations_primary.name: Thomas Edison
constellations_primary.description: Thomas Edison helped establish cinema as an art-form and mass entertainment. Many of his early films were short and showed everyday activities like riding a bicycle.

results.description: Thomas Edison daydreamed at school. Though his teachers were unimpressed, the American inventor later imagined numerous innovative devices and processes. He improved the telegraph system and created the first commercially practical light bulb, as well as the phonograph sound recorder. After seeing Eadweard Muybridge’s and Étienne-Jules Marey’s photography, Edison charged Scottish inventor William Dickson with developing the Kinetoscope, a large cabinet housing 50-foot loops of film that showed short movies on everything from dancing women to boxing cats. One film was Fred Ott’s Sneeze (1894), which, like many of the films, Dickson produced with another Edison invention, the Kinetograph, the first motion-picture camera. These inventions contributed to filmmaking as we know it – and prove it pays to daydream.
description_for_label: Thomas Edison daydreamed at school. Though his teachers were unimpressed, the American inventor later imagined numerous innovative devices and processes. He improved the telegraph system and created the first commercially practical light bulb, as well as the phonograph sound recorder. After seeing Eadweard Muybridge’s and Étienne-Jules Marey’s photography, Edison charged Scottish inventor William Dickson with developing the Kinetoscope, a large cabinet housing 50-foot loops of film that showed short movies on everything from dancing women to boxing cats. One film was Fred Ott’s Sneeze (1894), which, like many of the films, Dickson produced with another Edison invention, the Kinetograph, the first motion-picture camera. These inventions contributed to filmmaking as we know it – and prove it pays to daydream.

results.title: The Story of the Kelly Gang
results.credit_line: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.
results.brief_description: Produced in Melbourne in 1906, The Story of the Kelly Gang is the world’s first feature-length film. While most movies of its era only ran for about 12 minutes, Charles Tait’s bushranger epic went for over an hour.

constellations_primary.name: Outlawed
constellations_primary.description: From The Story of the Kelly Gang to Sweet Country, this Constellation explores bushrangers, samurai and bandits.

constellations_other.name: Crime doesn't pay
constellations_other.description: Ned Kelly's famous armour has appeared in many films, but the criminal myth speaks to how audiences have always been captivated by true-crime stories, from the beginning of cinema to today.

constellations_other.name: Bell & Howell Projector 621: This picture has been edited for content
constellations_other.description: The Bell & Howell-Gaumont Model 621 projector was originally used entertain the shearers on a sheep farm in South Australia with the films screened sometimes edited for distribution.

constellations_other.name: True blue, true crime
constellations_other.description: Robert Connolly's The Dry is a recent Australian crime blockbuster, but the writer, director and producer's first film (and first crime film) connects to a longstanding tradition of true-blue crime stories from some of our greatest filmmakers.

results.description:
Produced in Melbourne in 1906, The Story of the Kelly Gang is the world’s first feature-length film. While most movies of its era only ran for about 12 minutes, Charles Tait’s bushranger epic went for over an hour. But it wasn’t just the longest film by time: it was literally ‘the longest film ever made’, at a staggering 4,000 feet of celluloid.

Its popularity was also staggering, so much so that in 1914 the New South Wales government banned the production of bushranger films, believing that The Story of the Kelly Gang influenced rising crime. That’s debatable, but the film’s influence on other filmmakers isn’t.
description_for_label:
Produced in Melbourne in 1906, The Story of the Kelly Gang is the world’s first feature-length film. While most movies of its era only ran for about 12 minutes, Charles Tait’s bushranger epic went for over an hour. But it wasn’t just the longest film by time: it was literally ‘the longest film ever made’, at a staggering 4,000 feet of celluloid.

Its popularity was also staggering, so much so that in 1914 the New South Wales government banned the production of bushranger films, believing that The Story of the Kelly Gang influenced rising crime. That’s debatable, but the film’s influence on other filmmakers isn’t.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.
